title: Will Congress pass a resolution disapproving the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action?
possible_answers: Yes, but the resolution will be vetoed by the President and the veto will stand
Yes, and the resolution will become law
preds: Sept 17 is gone.  Trust the claim that the 60 day clock has not started yet, will fail.

It's over (really-really over this time!)
http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/254030-senate-dems-stonewall-iran-resolution-handing-victory-to-obama
"Senate Democrats blocked a resolution disapproving the Iran nuclear deal for a third time Thursday, sealing a major foreign policy victory for President Obama. 
Senators voted 56-42 against ending debate on the resolution of disapproval, falling short of the 60 votes needed on the procedural motion.
Democratic Sens. Ben Cardin (Md.), Joe Manchin (W.Va.), Bob Menendez (N.J.) and Charles Schumer (N.Y.) for a third time bucked Obama and voted "no" on moving to a final vote.
GOP Sens. Rand Paul (Ky.) and Marco Rubio (Fla.) missed the vote, while Sens. Ted Cruz (Texas) and Lindsey Graham (S.C.) voted to end debate. All four took part in Wednesday night's Republican presidential debate in California."

http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/253877-durbin-still-locking-down-votes-on-israel-hostages-amendment
"The Senate is expected to take a procedural vote Thursday on an amendment to the resolution of disapproval from Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. The Kentucky Republican wants to ban President Obama from lifting sanctions against Iran until Tehran publicly recognizes Israel's right to exist and releases Americans currently held in the country. 
...
Democrats will pick up at least two new votes in their quest to keep Republicans from getting the 60 votes needed to move forward with the amendment: Sens. Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) and Ben Cardin (D-Md.) Schumer and Cardin were two of the four Senate Democrats who support the Iran deal [this is a mistake, they support the resolution and oppose the deal], but aides to both senators confirmed that they would vote "no" on cloture for McConnell's amendment.  The maneuver could give more cover to Democrats who are concerned about any political fallout on the vote."
It can't get by the Senate.

Obama has becoming more bold as his Presidency wanes. Over the years, he has clashed with Israeli conservatives and expressed support for the plight of Palestinians. While not expressly 'thumbing his nose' at Israeli, he may view JCPOA as both 'the right thing to do' and payback for the perceived intransigence of Israeli leadership. As such, his Administration has lobbied hard to prevent Congressional opposition.  The House has voted against JCPOA, but Senate Democrats are preventing a vote via filibuster. He will not have to veto a bill opposing JCPOA because it will never reach his deck.
Obama and the Democrats have enough votes to pass it and Obama won't have to use his veto.

From: http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/iran-nuclear-deal-survives-as-disapproval-resolution-falls-in-senate/article26315944/ "That would be followed Friday by votes on a bill to approve the accord — which is doomed to fail, but Republicans want to force Democrats to go on record in favour of the agreement — and on a measure preventing Obama from lifting congressionally mandated sanctions on Iran." That's two separate things: - An inverse bill approving the accord, intended to fail in the House. That probably won't trigger closure of this question, since it won't be passed by either house.
- A measure preventing lifting of sanctions. If that passes the House, aside from the Senate issue, would this trigger closure of the question? It is clearly intended to derail the deal, but doesn't directly address it. I'm guessing this would NOT result in a "VETO" close, even if the President vetoes it, since it technically doesn't meet the question. In addition, there's the lawsuit issue, which I don't fully understand - but which I can't see having any effect on this question, regardless of outcome. I had a technical question before regarding exactly what "Congress" means, with regards to something that passes one (but not the other) of the houses. The confusion had to do with common usage of the word "congressman", which typically would only refer to a member of the House of Representatives. Thankfully Wikipedia cleared things up: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress In light of the above, I don't see any actions coming out of Congress that could cause this question to close as anything other than "NO" in the next month.

http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2015/09/10/senate-set-to-vote-on-iran-nuclear-deal/
"Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said the Senate will vote on the resolution of disapproval one more time before the Sept. 17 deadline to see “if any folks want to change their minds.” But he seemed to accept that there was no way to block it in Congress. “If we want to do anything further about this Iranian regime, bring me a bill with enough cosponsors to override a presidential veto,” McConnell told his colleagues after Thursday’s vote. “Otherwise, the American people will give us their judgment about the appropriateness of this measure a year from November.”"

Too late but put the #s in anyway  :-(    Thursday, September 10, 2015 4:08 PM EDT
Senate Democrats delivered a major victory to President Obama on Thursday when they blocked a Republican resolution to reject a six-nation nuclear accord with Iran, ensuring that the landmark deal will take effect without a veto showdown between Congress and the White House.
A procedural vote fell short of the number needed to break a Democratic filibuster. It culminated hours of debate on the Senate floor and capped months of discord since the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Russia and China announced the agreement with Iran in July.

http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/253163-mcconnell-sets-up-iran-vote
"Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) on Wednesday teed up a procedural vote on the Iran nuclear deal.  The Republican leader filed cloture on a resolution of disapproval of the Iran nuclear deal, as well as the House-passed shell bill that the Senate is using for the agreement. 

Under Senate rules that procedural tactic paves the way for a first vote on the Iran resolution Friday. McConnell, however, said Wednesday evening that his is "optimistic" a deal will be reached to have the vote on Thursday afternoon.
...
In the House, Republican leadership scuttled an expected vote on a resolution of disapproval, suggesting that even if a similar measure passes the Senate it would be dead on arrival in the lower chamber.

Instead House lawmakers are expected to vote on a resolution of approval, as well as a proposal to block Obama from lifting sanctions. "

I think I get it now. It's not Reid who needs 41 votes committed to a filibuster. It's McConnell who needs 60 votes for cloture to move on to a vote on the resolution. Meaning, he needs 2 out of 42 votes of the Democrats who announced their support for the deal. Now, it's one thing for a Democrat who supports the deal to support a filibuster - while it opens him or her to some criticism, it clearly helps the party and the deal.
But it's another thing to, first, vote - with the opponents of the deal - for ending the debate, then vote against the resolution with a regular threshold, then vote to uphold the Obama's veto. It opens such a Senator not only to more attacks, but from both sides (this is almost Greg Sargent's argument: https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2015/09/04/hey-democrats-its-a-trap/ - I just didn't really understand its implications). Meanwhile in the House:
http://thehill.com/policy/national-security/253146-house-gop-shakes-up-iran-strategy
if the House, instead of voting on a resolution disapproving the deal, tries and fails to adopt a resolution approving the deal, for us that's a "No".

http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/253099-durbin-dems-still-undecided-on-iran-filibuster
"Sen. Dick Durbin, the Senate's No. 2 Democrat, suggested Wednesday that he's still trying to shore up support for a filibuster of a resolution of disapproval on the Iran nuclear deal. 
"I will tell you this: We're working that question now," he told reporters when asked whether Democrats would be able to block the resolution. "We're down to three or four loose ends. There's been a positive response in the caucus — members understand. Let's get down to the bottom line here. What McConnell wants to do is ... drag this out at a time when we have precious little time for that kind of political exercise." " While I still believe Reid & co can pull this off, for Durbin to admit they're "3 or 4" votes short... Doesn't look good. Or is he trying to bait McConnell to invoke cloture and vote against it with full 41 (or even 42) votes?

So Cantwell's in:
http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/252997-cantwell-backs-iran-deal
"Cantwell added that she would also support a filibuster of the vote on a resolution to disapprove the deal." Blumenthal's in:
http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/253007-dem-mum-on-potential-iran-filibuster
"Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) told reporters he would back the filibuster after announcing his support for the deal earlier Tuesday." No info on Peters and Wyden. Also Coons, Heitkemp, Casey and Warner reported as undecided on filibuster (that's 2+4 of 42): "Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.) on Tuesday suggested he's undecided on a Democratic push to use a filibuster to block a resolution of disapproval on the Iran nuclear deal from passing the Senate. 
"We're going to be discussing that tomorrow and ... [we'll] see where things are," he said, in response to questions on whether he would support a filibuster, adding, "we'll see." 
Casey's office didn't respond to a request for comment on the senator's position.
 ... 
Casey, who backed the agreement last week, isn't alone on not committing to back a filibuster. Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.), Mark Warner (D-Va.) and Heidi Heitkamp (D-N.D.) have all remained tightlipped about whether they would vote "no" on cloture for the resolution of disapproval. 
Coons told CNN last week that “it would be really regrettable” if senators weren't able to take vote on the Iran deal." http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/252916-obama-wont-need-veto-pen-on-iran-nuclear-deal
“Reid is looking for a way not to go through a cloture vote because he’s doesn’t want to filibuster the Iran deal. We don’t want to make it easier for Democrats to defeat [the disapproval resolution,]” said Don Stewart, McConnell’s spokesman." http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/253045-reid-mcconnell-battle-ahead-of-iran-debate
"But McConnell rejected an offer from Reid on Tuesday that would have set up a vote for Thursday, while Reid rejected two attempts by McConnell to get consent to schedule votes. 
Reid added Wednesday that Democrats "are willing to have all the debate the Republicans want. Two hours. Two days. ...What we don't have time [for] is to waste on Republican-contrived procedural fights that have no basis of fact in reality." 
Reid's comments come as Democrats are expected to discuss a potential filibuster of the Iran resolution during a party lunch on Wednesday." If Harry Reid and the White House managed to convince almost all of the holdouts to support the deal, I believe they can convince them to filibuster the resolution.

There are now 41 senate democrats that publically support the Iran deal. As long as they stick together, there are now enough of them to prevent debate on the resolution, and the White House and Senate leadership seem to be okay with this approach. My only caution is that the margin for a filibuster is fairly narrow. If one or two senate democrats decide a debate is worth having or change their minds on the merits of the deal, the resolution would likely pass. In that case, a successful veto is still likely (as this would only require support of 34 senators).  Will continue to update as the rest of the senate democrats/independents stake out their position.  Source(s):
(1) http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2015/09/08/sen-joe-manchin-opposes-iran-deal-making-obama-veto-more-likely/
(2) http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/252933-white-house-ok-with-filibuster-of-iran-vote
Obama's got the numbers and the political pressure to ride a filibuster. Anything's possible, but I think there's enough breathing room for Senate Ds to kill the resolution.

Following Heffalump and cmeinel, but splitting the difference. Knowing they can't over-ride a presidential veto, the Republicans will seek the symbolic advantage of having passed the resolution and forcing a veto.  OTOH, even if the Democrats succeed in the increasingly unlikely task of collecting 41 Senators to sustain a filibuster, if it goes on for any length of time they'll lose whatever high ground they currently hold and will be blamed for wasting time on a frivolous exercise instead of producing meaningful legislation. That would also suit the Republicans. It would seem best for the Democrats not to go for a filibuster. This would make life easier for their remaining undecided senators, who have re-election prospects to consider, especially as the resolution is not going to become law (barring the black swan succession sequence indicated by Heffalump).

Pres has sufficient votes to sustain veto now, will get a few more over the next month, and the republicans will pass the resolution disapproval to try and create another issue they can attack in the current election cycle

Wasserman-Schultz announces support of deal, tearing up in the process:
http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2015/09/06/dnc-chair-debbie-wasserman-schultz-says-she-will-vote-for-iran-deal/ One must wonder how hard the D's are working to prevent cloture. http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/252843-reid-makes-offer-to-gop-on-iran
"I recently informed Senator McConnell that after a period of robust debate, Democrats would be happy to proceed straight to a final passage vote that is consistent with Senator McConnell’s many statements that important matters in the Senate have ‘for quite some time required sixty votes,’ " Reid said in a statement. "The choice is up to him."  What I hear Reid's saying is "We can have a filibuster that I may or may not have enough votes for, or we can have a straight yes or no vote with a seemingly equivalent 60 votes threshold so my Senators who support the deal but won't join the filibuster can vote down your resolution, and you'll have your excuse - hey, we gave Obama a good fight, 60 votes was not happening anyway, elect more Republicans etc etc." What do the White House and Reid have now (not counting Democratic Senators who oppose the deal):
- 36 senators: deal - "yes", filibuster - "yes",
- 2 senators (Coons, Heitkamp): deal - "yes", filibuster - "unknown",
- 4 senators (Blumenthal, Cantwell, Peters, Wyden): deal - "unknown", filibuster - "unknown",
- 1 senator (Manchin): deal - "unknown", filibuster - "no".
So for a filibuster they need to convince 5 out of 6 (to get to 41), while for a straight yes/no vote (with the same threshold) they need 3 out of 5.
Naturally, this is a good trade for them (a higher chance to kill the resolution without a messy veto process). Now, let's see this from McConnell's perspective:
- the resolution dies anyway (whether by an under-60-votes-threshold vote, a lack of vote due to a filibuster, or by a regular-threshold-vote and a veto), so the question is who gets what out of the process itself;
- I suppose it's more important for him to let Republican Senators go on record voting against the deal rather than just embarrass Reid and the White House at any price;
- a successful filibuster denies the Republicans a chance to go on record;
- while a yes/no vote gives them exactly that opportunity. So if the filibuster threat seems credible, it might be better for McConnell not to call Reid's bluff and just set up a 60-votes-threshold yes/no vote.
At this point, it does not seem credible to me - there are some of the undecided Democrats that might announce not just against the filibuster, but against the deal itself (Blumenthal, Peters, Wyden). McConnell will probably wait until the very last moment to see if any of the Democrats cave to the pressure from the deal's opponents (and if they don't, he can take a safer route and set up a yes/no vote), so will I.

There are enough votes for a veto to hold, so the likelihood of Yes seems remote.  Latest indicates 4 more votes required to support a filibuster attempt, with 6 undeclared Dems.  That's far from certain.

The White House has already shored up enough Senate votes to make sure this deal sticks. That's good news for them, but there's still a great deal of political points to be gained/lost if the GOP can force Obama to use his veto. Reid & Co. are looking for the fastest way out of this dogfight, and that's by promising future concessions to the still-undecided Democrats. They'll pay out the nose for every vote up to 41.

"Democrats will try to mount a filibuster to block the Iran nuclear deal from even having to reach President Obama’s desk for a veto, Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid signaled Saturday.   Reid has enough committed supporters to sustain an Obama veto and allow the Iran deal to proceed, but a filibuster would be an even bigger coup, halting the issue earlier in the process. A filibuster would avoid the need for Democrats to cast more politically fraught votes." "A surge of support for Mr. Obama’s stance this week has put Democrats well over the 34 votes needed to guarantee upholding the veto, and they are now within striking distance of the 41 votes that would guarantee a filibuster, too." "The latest count from the Bipartisan Policy Center puts them at 38 supporters — 36 Democrats and two liberal-leaning independents.  They need 41." "Just 33 senators have announced their opposition, and 29 have yet to give an official stance, including five Democrats."

Going back towards my initial inclination. 60 votes are needed to end a filibuster, With Joe Manchin, the Democrats now have 39, so would need at least 2 out of the remaining 4 - my personal opinion is that they are unlikely to get more than two. Further, Manchin has said he won't back a filibuster, and earlier Chris Coons had also said he wanted an up and down vote. http://www.dailykos.com/story/2015/09/04/1418407/-Bennet-becomes-38th-Democratic-senator-to-back-Iran-pact-Cardin-becomes-3rd-Democrat-to-oppose# The question is will Manchin and Coons be part of the 60 required to end a filibuster? If they just abstain, the Democrats  need only two more out of the remaining four.  If they actively vote to end or avoid a filibuster, then the resolution could still end up on the President's desk. This looks to me to be on a knife edge right now, at least until further announcements.

Unless the GOP simply becomes too engrossed in its presidential campaign and tired of just thwarting the President, they'll vote the deal down.  He'll veto it and they simply don't have the votes to override the veto.

Level of effort: daily news observations and checking other predictioneers' reports, given that it is crunch time in Iran and the U.S., the only countries with a credible likelihood, however small, to ditch the deal. U.S. Republicans now are promoting an end run around the Iran nuclear deal that is apparently designed to persuade Iran to reject the agreement. The concept is for U.S. states to impose new sanctions against Iran in addition to the existing sanctions, primarily divestments similar to those imposed against South Africa during the era of apartheid.  If this tactic were to succeed, the most likely outcome apparently would be no Senate vote, as the issue would be moot. On the other hand, Republicans might push for a Senate show vote, hoping to declare a victory that would open the checkbooks of their base, while Democrats might duck and cover, no filibuster, allowing it to reach Obama's desk for his own show veto. On the other hand, given that all members of the UN Security Council have voted in favor of the agreement, and given the power of the UNSC to lift sanctions, Republicans' state sanctions effort might at most be viewed by Iranian politicians as pin pricks. Indeed, the rabid opposition in Iranian might instead see that if Republicans + Netanyahu's camp say the agreement is so good for Iran, then the politically expedient course would be to tell their base that the agreement must be the perfect “death to Israel” move. Sources: Dateline 9-2-15 With hawkish Democrats Bob Casey and Chris Coons all but ensuring opponents won’t have a veto-proof majority in the US Senate, the states are coming under pressure to pass their own sanctions. The Republican attorneys general of Oklahoma and Michigan, Scott Pruitt and Bill Schuette, wrote a letter to their counterparts Sept. 1 urging them to do just that. “The states certainly have numerous moral and reputational reasons to prohibit investment of public assets into companies doing business with Iran and other countries that sponsor terrorism,” they wrote. “Even if it is true that Iran has relinquished its ambitions for a nuclear weapon and that its deal with President [Barack] Obama will prevent such an acquisition — both of which are highly questionable — Iran engages in a range of other reprehensible activities.”

Do the oppositional voices in Iran give energy to same in Congress? - LH http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/04/world/middleeast/ayatollah-ali-khamenei-iran-supreme-leader-nuclear-deal-vote.html?_r=0 TEHRAN — A day after President Obama secured enough votes to ensure approval of the Iranian nuclear deal in the United States Congress, Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Thursday ordered Parliament to vote on the agreement and threatened to cancel the pact entirely if the West merely suspended, rather than canceled, economic sanctions, state news media reported. While the Iranian Parliament is expected to approve the agreement, the announcement nonetheless represented a setback for President Hassan Rouhani and his team of nuclear negotiators, who have long held that the deal should be ratified by the Supreme National Security Council, which Mr. Rouhani heads. Their fear is that a debate in Parliament will provide a platform for strident, archconservative opponents of the pact.

The remaining uncertainty, IMHO, is over whether the Republicans could overcome the inevitable filibuster in the Senate and force a vote, and then win the vote. Note that Senators, holding 6-year terms, tend to be less swayed by the heat of the moment.  Comparison class: Obamacare. Despite dozens of votes in the House to repeal it, Obamacare repeal has been unable to pass the Senate. Given today's promises of support from Coons and Casey, and the likelihood that the remaining one supporter required to veto-proof the agreement will materialize soon, either Republicans will fail to beat the filibuster, or the vote will fail, meaning that either way, Congress will consequently fail to pass the resolution. Wildcard: It still is not a done deal over in Iran.
